definitions.definition: something that you allow or do, or allow somebody to have, in order to end an argument or to make a situation less difficult

examples.text: The firm will be forced to **make concessions** if it wants to avoid a strike.
to win a concession from somebody
She **made no concession** to his inexperience as a manager.
The company will be forced to make concessions to the union.
The pressure group has won a number of concessions on environmental policy.
She makes no concessions to public opinion whatsoever.
They remained unwilling to make any substantial concessions.

definitions.definition: the act of giving something or allowing something; the act of conceding

examples.text: the concession of university status to some colleges
her **concession speech** *(= when she admitted that she had lost the election)*
Military support was offered in return for the concession of territory.

definitions.definition: a reduction in an amount of money that has to be paid; a ticket that is sold at a reduced price to a particular group of people

examples.text: They may grant tax concessions to encourage foreign investors.
Tickets are £3; there is a £1 concession for students.
Travel concessions are available to older people.

definitions.definition: a right or an advantage that is given to a group of people, an organization, etc., especially by a government or an employer

examples.text: The Bolivian government has granted logging concessions covering 22 million hectares.
The company has just won a mining concession in the north of the country.

definitions.definition: the right to sell something in a particular place; the place where you sell it, sometimes an area that is part of a larger building or store

examples.text: the burger concessions at the stadium
They went to the **concession stand** to get a hot dog.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Latin concessio(n-), from the verb concedere, from con- ‘completely’ + cedere ‘yield’.
